### DefaultSafeSPDisplacement {#a149e6ac957dbd4ac7a2d1b0b01b30bdf}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="const unsigned DefaultSafeSPDisplacement = 255"
  labels = {["static"]}>
This is the biggest offset to the stack pointer we can encode in aarch64 instructions (without using a separate calculation and a temp register).

<Link id="l00081" /><CodeLine lineNumber="81"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00082" /><CodeLine lineNumber="82"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// To access the data in a frame, at-compile time, a constant offset must be</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00083" /><CodeLine lineNumber="83"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// computable from one of the pointers (fp, bp, sp) to access it. The size</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00087" /><CodeLine lineNumber="87"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// assuming all of the frame areas are non-empty.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00088" /><CodeLine lineNumber="88"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00089" /><CodeLine lineNumber="89"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For most functions, some of the frame areas are empty. For those functions,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00090" /><CodeLine lineNumber="90"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// it may not be necessary to set up fp or bp:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00091" /><CodeLine lineNumber="91"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// &#42; A base pointer is definitely needed when there are both VLAs and local</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00092" /><CodeLine lineNumber="92"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   variables with more-than-default alignment requirements.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00093" /><CodeLine lineNumber="93"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// &#42; A frame pointer is definitely needed when there are local variables with</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00094" /><CodeLine lineNumber="94"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   more-than-default alignment requirements.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00095" /><CodeLine lineNumber="95"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00096" /><CodeLine lineNumber="96"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For Darwin platforms the frame-record (fp, lr) is stored at the top of the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00097" /><CodeLine lineNumber="97"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// callee-saved area, since the unwind encoding does not allow for encoding</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00098" /><CodeLine lineNumber="98"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// this dynamically and existing tools depend on this layout. For other</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00099" /><CodeLine lineNumber="99"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// platforms, the frame-record is stored at the bottom of the (gpr) callee-saved</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00100" /><CodeLine lineNumber="100"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// area to allow SVE stack objects (allocated directly below the callee-saves,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00101" /><CodeLine lineNumber="101"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// if available) to be accessed directly from the framepointer.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00102" /><CodeLine lineNumber="102"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The SVE spill/fill instructions have VL-scaled addressing modes such</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00103" /><CodeLine lineNumber="103"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// as:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00104" /><CodeLine lineNumber="104"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//    ldr z8, &#91;fp, #-7 mul vl&#93;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00105" /><CodeLine lineNumber="105"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For SVE the size of the vector length (VL) is not known at compile-time, so</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00106" /><CodeLine lineNumber="106"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// &#39;#-7 mul vl&#39; is an offset that can only be evaluated at runtime. With this</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00107" /><CodeLine lineNumber="107"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// layout, we don&#39;t need to add an unscaled offset to the framepointer before</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00108" /><CodeLine lineNumber="108"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// accessing the SVE object in the frame.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00109" /><CodeLine lineNumber="109"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00110" /><CodeLine lineNumber="110"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// In some cases when a base pointer is not strictly needed, it is generated</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00111" /><CodeLine lineNumber="111"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// anyway when offsets from the frame pointer to access local variables become</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00114" /><CodeLine lineNumber="114"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00115" /><CodeLine lineNumber="115"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Outgoing function arguments must be at the bottom of the stack frame when</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00116" /><CodeLine lineNumber="116"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// calling another function. If we do not have variable-sized stack objects, we</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00120" /><CodeLine lineNumber="120"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// make space for the arguments below the VLAs.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00121" /><CodeLine lineNumber="121"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00122" /><CodeLine lineNumber="122"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// FIXME: also explain the redzone concept.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00123" /><CodeLine lineNumber="123"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00124" /><CodeLine lineNumber="124"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// About stack hazards: Under some SME contexts, a coprocessor with its own</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00125" /><CodeLine lineNumber="125"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// separate cache can used for FP operations. This can create hazards if the CPU</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00126" /><CodeLine lineNumber="126"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// and the SME unit try to access the same area of memory, including if the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00127" /><CodeLine lineNumber="127"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// access is to an area of the stack. To try to alleviate this we attempt to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00128" /><CodeLine lineNumber="128"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// introduce extra padding into the stack frame between FP and GPR accesses,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00129" /><CodeLine lineNumber="129"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// controlled by the aarch64-stack-hazard-size option. Without changing the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00130" /><CodeLine lineNumber="130"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// layout of the stack frame in the diagram above, a stack object of size</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00131" /><CodeLine lineNumber="131"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// aarch64-stack-hazard-size is added between GPR and FPR CSRs. Another is added</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00132" /><CodeLine lineNumber="132"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// to the stack objects section, and stack objects are sorted so that FPR &gt;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00133" /><CodeLine lineNumber="133"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Hazard padding slot &gt; GPRs (where possible). Unfortunately some things are</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00134" /><CodeLine lineNumber="134"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// not handled well (VLA area, arguments on the stack, objects with both GPR and</span></CodeLine>
